questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent low mood, loss of interest, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness, and occasional thoughts of self-harm for the past six months. She has a family history of depression. Diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD), she is started on paroxetine. Which class of drug does paroxetine fall under?

A 28-year-old man presents with excessive worry, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and disturbed sleep for several months. He also experiences occasional panic attacks with palpitations, sweating, and a sense of impending doom. With a family history of anxiety disorders, he is diagnosed with Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). Which of the following medications is most appropriate for initial treatment?
Which of the following is not true for SSRIs?

options.label: A
options.text: Paroxetine is not safe in pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Sertraline is safe to use with warfarin

options.label: D
options.text: Escitalopram is preferred in those with heart disease

questions.correct_answer: C. Fluoxetine is the shortest-acting SSRI

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbances for the past six months. She describes the pain as dull and achy, affecting various areas like the neck, shoulders, back, and hips, with heightened sensitivity at tender points. After ruling out other conditions, she is diagnosed with fibromyalgia. Which medication is most appropriate for initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Fibromyalgia

Details

Definition

A chronic condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive impairment (often referred to as "fibro fog").

Pathophysiology

The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to involve central sensitization, where the brain processes pain signals abnormally.

Clinical Features

Widespread pain in areas like the neck, shoulders, back, hips.

Fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive dysfunction (fibro fog).

Tenderness at specific points on the body.

Diagnosis

Primarily clinical, based on symptoms and the exclusion of other conditions. There is no definitive laboratory test for fibromyalgia.

Treatment

Pharmacologic treatment includes medications like SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors), SNRIs (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors), and anticonvulsants like pregabalin. Non-pharmacologic approaches include physical therapy, exercise, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of involuntary bedwetting during sleep at least twice a week for the past 6 months. Physical examination and laboratory investigations reveal no abnormalities. The child has no daytime urinary symptoms or signs of urinary tract infection. After ruling out organic causes, what is the most appropriate pharmacological treatment for this condition?

A 45-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder is prescribed amitriptyline for the management of her depression. She has been on the medication for two weeks. . Which of the following side effects is most likely associated with the use of amitriptyline in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade
  • Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma)
  • Urinary retention (option C)
  • Constipation (Option A)
  • Tachycardia

Increase in serotonin in the brain
  • Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism
  • Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about MAO inhibitors?

options.label: A
options.text: Use with sympathomimetics can cause hypertensive crisis

options.label: B
options.text: It is contraindicated with tyramine-rich food

options.label: C
options.text: Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor

questions.correct_answer: D. Routinely used to treat depression
questions.explanation:
Types of MAO Inhibitors

Examples

Non-selective MAOIs

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Selective MAO-A inhibitors

Moclobemide

Selective MAO-B inhibitors

Selegiline, Rasagiline (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antidepressants has the maximum risk of seizures?
questions.explanation:
Bupropion (Option D)
  • Norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor
  • Used for smoking cessation and weight loss
  • High risk of seizures

Trazodone (Option B)
  • Serotonin antagonist (5HT2 blocker) and reuptake inhibitor
  • DOC-Depression + erectile dysfunction
  • No sexual dysfunction side effects
  • No nausea and vomiting side effects
  • Can cause priapism

Mirtazapine, Mianserin (Option C)
  • Noradrenaline and selective serotonin antagonist
  • Side effects: Somnolescence, increased appetite, and weight gain
  • Used in depression with insomnia

Buspirone, Gepirone (Option A)
  • 5HT1a receptor partial agonist
  • Used to treat generalised anxiety disorder

Tianeptine
  • Serotonin reuptake enhancer
  • It also acts on opioid receptors and stimulates them
  • Used to treat depression

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, altered mental status, tachycardia, rigidity, dilated pupils, clonus, and diarrhea after increasing his SSRI dose. He reports that he recently started taking a new over-the-counter supplement for mood enhancement. The doctor prescribed him cyproheptadine. For which condition is cyproheptadine used as an antidote?

A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent and intractable hiccups for the past 48 hours. He describes the hiccups as occurring every few seconds, significantly affecting his ability to eat, sleep, and carry out daily activities. He denies any recent changes in his diet or lifestyle and has no significant medical history. On examination, he appears anxious and distressed due to the hiccups. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for treating intractable hiccups in this patient?

A 70-year-old man with a 10-year history of Parkinson's disease presents to the clinic with complaints of visual hallucinations and delusional thinking, which have been progressively worsening over the past few months. He is started on an atypical antipsychotic to address his psychotic symptoms. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug?
questions.explanation:
PIMAVANSERIN

Mechanism of Action

Clinical Use

Adverse effects
  • Pimavanserin is a novel antipsychotic drug.
  • Primarily acts through inverse agonism of serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.
  • Does not appreciably bind to 5-HT2B or other monoaminergic receptors.
  • Treats hallucinations and psychosis in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients
  • Alleviates psychotic symptoms without worsening PD motor symptoms
  • Lacks dopamine receptor antagonism, reducing the risk of worsening motor symptoms
  • Suitable for PD patients intolerant to traditional antipsychotics (due to dopamine receptor blocking effects)
  • Carries a black-box warning for increased mortality in elderly patients.
  • Essential to monitor QT interval due to the risk of QT prolongation and potential cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has been diagnosed with schizophrenia for over 15 years. Despite multiple trials of antipsychotic medications, including risperidone, olanzapine, and quetiapine, he continues to experience severe and persistent psychotic symptoms. His psychiatrist decides to start clozapine due to the treatment-resistant nature of his schizophrenia. Which of the following does NOT best describe the drug?

options.label: D
options.text: Wet pillow syndrome is a known side effect

questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action

Atypical antipsychotic with weak dopamine D2 receptor antagonism.

Exhibits potent antagonism at serotonin 5HT2A receptors.

Blocks 5HT2A receptors more strongly than D2 receptors.

Uses of Clozapine

Schizophrenia

DOC for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

Effective for schizophrenia with suicidality, polydipsia, or persistent impulsive aggression.

Mania (Option A)

Beneficial as adjunctive therapy or monotherapy for resistant mania.

Lower Risk of EPS

(Option B)

Significantly lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) due to its weaker D2 antagonism compared to typical antipsychotics.

Other Uses

Used to treat antipsychotic-induced tardive dyskinesia.

Serious Adverse Effects of Clozapine

Description

Agranulocytosis
  • Rare but life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, requiring weekly monitoring.
  • Discontinue if total leukocyte count < 3000/mm³ or absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm³.
  • Avoid combining with carbamazepine.
  • Monitoring of agranulocytosis: 1st 6 weeks - weekly; Next 6 months- Fortnightly; After 1 year- Monthly

Seizures
  • Dose-dependent seizure risk. Higher than other atypical antipsychotics.

Cardiac Effects
  • Risk of tachycardia, myocarditis (fatal, within first 6 wks) and dilated cardiomyopathy.

Non-serious Adverse effects of Clozapine

Description

Hypersalivation (Option D)
  • Known as "wet pillow syndrome" due to muscarinic receptor stimulation.

Metabolic Complications
  • Significant risk of weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
  • Associated with increased appetite due to 5-HT2C receptor blockade.

Cataracts
  • Higher risk than other atypical antipsychotics.

Effect in Pregnancy and Breastfeeding
  • Can cause decreased arousal and hypotonia in neonates.
  • C/I during breastfeeding due to the risk of neutropenia, sedation, and seizures in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications is considered the safest in pregnancy due to its minimal crossing of the placenta?

A 40-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia has been prescribed an antipsychotic medication for the past few months. She presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle stiffness, restlessness, and occasional tremors. During the examination, the physician noted her difficulty sitting still and observed her hands shaking intermittently. Which of the following symptoms is NOT a presentation associated with antipsychotic drugs?
questions.explanation:
Typical Antipsychotics

Atypical Antipsychotics
  • Haloperidol - highest risk
  • Butyrophenones - potent D2 blockers with a high risk.
  • Thioxanthenes -lower prolactin risk (least D2 blocking activity)
  • Risperidone and paliperidone - high risk (due to ￪ P-glycoprotein affinity)
  • Pimavanserin and clozapine - lowest risk.

 

Condition

Onset

Treatment

Acute muscle Dystonia (Option C)

Within 1-5 days of starting antipsychotic

Administering antiparkinsonian agents such as diphenhydramine or benztropine intramuscularly.

Parkinsonism

Within 1 month

Benzhexol and benztropine (NOT Levodopa)

Akathisia (Option B)

(Most common EPS)

5–60 days

Anti-anxiety medications

  1. DOC: Propranolol (C/I: Asthma)
  2. Diazepam

Rabbit Syndrome

Months or years
  1. Antiparkinsonian agents.
  2. Amantadine is preferred due to less adverse cognitive effects.

Tardive Dyskinesia (Option A)

Late-onset adverse effect (after months or years)

Occurs due to D2 receptor supersensitivity and can be permanent, even after discontinuing antipsychotic medication.

Stop AP drugs & start Clozapine.

If symptoms persist, add Dopamine depleters (VMAT2 inhibitors)

  1. Valbenazine
  2. Tetrabenazine: DOC for Huntington's disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to severe agitation and aggressive behaviour. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder and is prescribed olanzapine, lithium, and fluoxetine. Temperature is 40.6 C (105.1 F), BP is 157/90 mm Hg. The patient requires several doses of antipsychotics to calm down. Examination shows diffuse rigidity in the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following most likely explains this patient's current symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)
(Option C)

Serotonin Syndrome
(Option D)

Mechanism

Associated with high doses of potent D2 antagonists

Mediated by activation of 5HT2A and 5HT1A receptors (serotonergic agents)

Associated Drugs

Antipsychotic agents (greater risk with 1st generation than 2nd generation)

SSRIs, NE reuptake inhibitors, triptans, MAOIs.

Onset

1-3 days

May persist for more than a week after the offending agent is discontinued

<1 day

Occur when starting new or increasing antidepressant therapy or combining an SSRI with an NE reuptake inhibitor or a triptan.

Common features

Altered mental status

Sympathetic hyperactivity (eg, hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis)

Distinct features

Lead pipe rigidity, hyporeflexia, elevated enzymes (↑ CK), myoglobinuria

Clonus, hyperreflexia

Treatment

Cessation of antipsychotic, supportive care (e.g., aggressive cooling measures), DA agonist (e.g., bromocriptine), dantrolene, ECT

Cessation of drugs, benzodiazepines, supportive care, cyproheptadine (serotonin agonist) if symptoms persist.

Avoid simultaneous serotonergic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications is typically associated with a higher incidence of akathisia?
